advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-150 was widely used in industry by engineers and scientists.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Imagine the new world that would unfold before you if you had a powerful , portable, completely integrated computer system at your personal disposal. And at an affordable price. That's exactly what Hewlett-Packard has just created.<br> At the lab, on your desk or in your study this 20-pound, self-contained system provides professional computing power when and where you need it. That means no more waiting for data to be remotely processed and returned.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"List your technical requirements, Hewlett-Packard is ready to answer"</blockquote>

computer.description:
The HP-85 was a famous all-in-one computer which met a great worldwide success thanks to its high reliability and ease of use. It featured a 8 bit processor, 16 KB of RAM, a built-in 5" CRT display, tape drive, thermal printer and four I/O ports. The HP custom processor had 64 8-bit registers but no accumulators. Even slow, it offered outstanding performances in math calculations. The display offered a full screen editor and and a ROLL key allowing to scroll the screen window up and down through a 48 line (three full screens) buffer . The quiet and quite fast printer could print a hard copy of the screen in text or graphic mode as well as direct programs outputs. The built-in tape cartridge system used a common DC100 data cartridge that could hold 195 KB of program files, binary files or data files. Up to 42 file names could be stored in the directory of the tape. A searching function made a file to be found in less than 1 mn. When the system was switched on, the tape drive automatically searched a program called 'Autost' and ran it if found.
HP also provided a large range of interface modules to be plugged in the expansion slots. The system could then manage several peripherals through GPIB or Serial ports: FDD unit, printers, plotters, etc. A 'ROM Drawer' module allowed up to six ROM chips to be inserted. They expanded the capabilities of the internal BASIC interpreter, provided additional languages (Assembler, Pascal), and I/O routines for external devices. A quite special "feature" of the HP-85 was that the screen blanked whenever the printer was printing or the cartridge was accessed!
computer.keyboard: Full stroke 93 keys with numeric keypad and user definable keys
computer.name: HP-85
computer.peripherals: Various extension cards: GP-IB, Serial, FDD controller, I/O routines, Parallel, BASIC extensions
computer.ram: 16 KB (14.5 KB for the user, expandable to 32 KB)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT VIEW #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT VIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN USE</strong></font><br><blockquote>After a self-test was performed, the character set in ROM is displayed and printed.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISPLAY DETAIL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE CATALOG LISTED</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>The expansions housing is here fitted with:<br> <b>(1)</b> a ROM drawer module<br> <b>(2)</b> a 128 KB RAM module<br> <b>(3)</b> a Serial interface module<br><br> Lot of expansion modules were developped for the HP-85.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ROM DRAWER MODULES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each ROM module could receive up to 6 ROM chips used for I/O or peripherals management, or offering advanced BASIC routines.<br> The ROM chips pictured are:<br> <b>(1)</b> General I/O routines<br> <b>(2)</b> Statistic routines<br> <b>(3)</b> Advanced programmer routines<br> <b>(4)</b> Printer-plotter management<br> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER & DC100 DRIVE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The thermal printer operates in both alphanumeric (128 ASCII character set) and graphics mode. The full character set can be underlined. The printer speed is 2 lines per second. <br><br> Cardridge rewind time is 29 seconds, search speed is 60 inches per second, data transfer speed is 10 inches per second and the tape length is 141 feet.<br> When turned on, the HP 85 looks for a program called "AUTOST" on the tape and executes it if it's found. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the contrast ajustment <b>(1)</b> and... the genuine HP roll of thermal paper!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOME OF THE CARTRIDGE TAPES</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://myworld.ebay.com/la-tech-renewal/" target="_blank">La-Tech-Renewal (Ebay Seller)</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> A DC100 CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each cardridge can hold 780 program records consisting of 192 KB each, or 850 data records of 210 KB. There can be a maximum of 42 named files per cardridge. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MANUALS SET</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of manuals delivered with the HP-85. Each of them is very clear and detailed. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Electronic part of the HP-85 is reliable, clear and really well designed. We can consider it as the most accomplished design of the computer industry of the time. <br><br> <b>(1)</b> Video board<br> <b>(2)</b> Power regulation board<br> <b>(3)</b> Printer mechanism<br> <b>(4)</b> Logic board<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LOGIC BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This board only contains main components of the computer. All of the secondary and passive components are located in video and power boards.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Expansion connectors cable<br> <b>(2)</b> Power board cable<br> <b>(3)</b> Printer - tape drive cable<br> <b>(4)</b> 16 KB RAM memory chips<br> <b>(5)</b> Processor and HP custom I/O chips<br> <b>(6)</b> 32 KB ROM chips<br> <b>(7)</b> Video board cable<br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRINTER UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Printer and tape drive unit.<br><br> Notice the surrounded signatures. One founds inside the machine about 15 different quality control signatures of the guy who built it. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>... with plotter, printer and double disk-drive unit</blockquote>
